title: There was a time in LoL's history when people actually made threads about how balanced and fun itwas
body:
Cinderhulk patch. Remember those front-paged threads about how almost every champ was viable?
People were **REJOICING** about how they could play whatever they want and not feel like trash. 
Assassins were viable but weren't overbearing. Fighters and Tanks could coexist. ADC were bot laned DPS carries. AP was fun to play..
Many of the 'unviable' picks found their spot in the game.

A time when both  {{champion:238}}  and {{champion:14}} were playable. Now one shits on mages harder than ever and the other is a handicap.

Now, you either pick the OP's or lose. 
**Winning games do not feel rewarding**. 
Losing games feel more frustrating than ever.

The reason people make these complaint threads is because we love the game and we don't want to see it go down the drain.

Okay then?

It's worth remembering that even if that's true, that doesn't necessarily make him wrong. The boards will filled with tons of complaints about the champions that were abusing it. Sej, Sion, Shyv, Gragas, Rek'sai (maybe more) in the jungle, Garen, Renekton, and a few more in top, tank supports abusing Cinderhulk as well, while using the smite for extra objective control (that wasn't the bad part, just part of the reasoning that helped the supports justify using it while abusing Cinderhulk). 

I also distinctly remember Mages actually complaining harder than assassins, because many of the mages couldn't keep up with the absurd tankiness of the enemy's potentially 3-4 man frontline with the papier mâché cannon in the back trying their best to not get killed by the tank. Assassins could at least try to maneuver or flank the tanks and get that aforementioned cannon, but most mages can't reliably do that and get away with it due to their lower mobility, and even if they did get there, their damage was generally lower so they couldn't guarantee the kill, and they couldn't be a huge threat to the frontline with their damage, either.

Then there was a super nerfed cinderhulk meta with super nerfed tanks as well that just ruined everything. If Riot had stopped the nerf train about halfway through the process everyone would have been thrilled all season. This is nitpicking but yes you are correct in that it was the pinnacle of balance for League and everybody was on the boards all the time incredibly happy with things for the most part.

That nerf train was bound for World's station, and Riot was prepared to run down every tank on the tracks. Tanky champs tend to foil flashier champs and their big plays, so they had to go.

It's also the reason why Lee's ult got mysteriously buffed around the same time; as if to encourage pros to use him and his esports friendly kit.

Joking aside, no, there has never been a time where the community did not complain about how imbalanced the game is. I've been here since September 2010, and even way back then players were whining about how 'X' champ was op, and how 'Y' skill was broken. It's simply the nature of a constantly changing game. There never will be true balance, and we don't truly ***want*** there to be true balance.

When it comes to balance actual champion balancing is only one aspect as is is items and how champions interact with them. Similar to how Blue Ezreal was always only okay but now that Armor is really weak and IBG is better and Blue Ezreal is one of the most dominant builds in the game despite Ezreal himself not really changing.

There is definitely some balance but there is alot of imbalance born of unnecessary changes that only serve to create drastic new problems until Riot eventually figures out that they had to simply correct the original imbalance in the first place to fix it.

The current meta is perfectly fine. You can play whatever you want, both in the jungle and in lane, and you're still able to win if you're good at the game.
The Cinderhulk meta was boring: too slow, with 40+ minutes game, and you were able to play only 1 strategy: teamfights.

Sure, there are some black sheeps in this meta (like {{champion:114}}, {{champion:77}} and {{champion:223}}), but you can ban them and play your game just fine.
Proof of this is the fact that you don't even have a name for this meta: you can play warrior junglers, runic echoes junglers, cinderhulk junglers and devourer junglers and you have the same possibility to win with each and everyone of them.
It is the jungle that dictates the speed of the meta and games are starting to last between 25 and 35 minutes because anything goes.
